The shadows of the evening were closing in, and the smithy had been deserted for some time, when a man came picking his way carefully over the uneven ground, and through the grass and mud towards it. He carried under his arm a bundle wrapped in an old newspaper, and he walked on tiptoe, as if anxious to avoid making the least noise. He looked fearfully about him, at intervals, as if he half expected to be pursued. When he reached the smithy, he set down his bundle on the ground, and, taking off his hat, wiped his forehead with a greasy handkerchief. He then stooped down to examine the fastenings of the door, which were secured by a padlock and chain. After a moment's hesitation, he produced a key from his pocket and, with a trembling hand, inserted it into the lock. The key turned with difficulty, and he had to exert considerable force before the lock clicked open. He then removed the chain and pushed the door open, revealing the dimly lit interior of the smithy. The man stepped inside, still carrying his bundle, and closed the door behind him. The sound of the closing door echoed faintly in the quiet evening air. He leaned against the door for a moment, catching his breath, before cautiously moving deeper into the smithy. The interior was cluttered with various tools and equipment, casting long, ominous shadows in the fading light. The man's eyes darted around, searching for a place to hide his bundle. He finally settled on a dark corner near the back of the smithy, where the shadows seemed to be deepest. Carefully, he unwrapped the bundle, revealing a small, worn leather pouch. He hesitated for a moment, his hand hovering over the pouch, before he finally opened it. The contents of the pouch glittered faintly in the dim light, catching his eye. It was a collection of small, intricately carved stones, each one unique in its design. He counted them carefully, his expression growing more anxious with each passing moment. As he finished counting, a sudden noise outside the smithy made him freeze. His heart pounded in his chest as he listened intently, straining to discern the source of the sound. It was only the distant bark of a dog, but in his heightened state of fear, it felt like a harbinger of danger. He quickly wrapped the stones back into the pouch, secured it within the bundle, and hurriedly rewrapped it. With one last anxious glance around the smithy, he made his way back to the door. He unlocked the padlock and chain with trembling hands, his movements more hurried and less cautious than before. Once the door was open, he stepped out into the twilight, casting one final look over his shoulder before disappearing into the gathering darkness. The smithy stood silent and still, the only evidence of his visit being the disturbed ground and the slightly ajar door.

The men danced, leaped, and sung; the women, with their arms entwined, and their long hair streaming, bounded in the circles that were formed about the fiercest dancers, and sang responses to the men. The eyes of all participants were fixed upon two men who, belaboured with red caps and armed with pikes that had been taken from the National Guard when it was disbanded, led the furious ring. These leaders, turning suddenly from the middle of the street into the little public garden opposite to the wood-sawyer’s door, the crowd followed with loud shouts and increased animation, while other hundreds poured in from various quarters to swell their numbers. The garden was one of the small public gardens that are to be found here and there in the French cities, generally with a fountain, and not unfrequently with a little summer-house or arbour in a retired nook. There was such a one here, with a fountain playing in the midst of it, and over the fountain a statue of the Goddess of Liberty. At sight of this, the two leaders, dropping for the moment the pikes they twirled, took off their caps, and, falling on their knees, hailed the Goddess of Liberty with loud and fervent bursts of applause. The rest, following their example, one and all went down upon their knees, and all made a great show of embracing one another under the statue, and then separating to form a variety of groups and to act little ensample scenes of a highly fanciful and not over-intelligible nature. The fountain had been turned off, and a cask of wine had been brought in and tapped, which was freely distributed to the assemblage. The men who had been most active in the dance reappeared in red caps, and were now in a manner at the head of the people, though all distinctions of head or tail were confounded under the common impulse. The two leaders again took their pikes, and danced and capered before the company, who roared applause. A shrill whistle was heard at a distance, and immediately afterwards a man came running in from the street, delivering a letter with great importance, and evidently in a considerable fright. The letter was from the Marquis St. Evrémonde, and contained a formal request that the bearer might be presented to the assembly, and heard by them. The man who brought it was admitted to the spot where the leaders stood, and delivered it with the required solemnity. The letter was read with great attention, and when its contents were known, a profound silence followed. The leaders then called for the bearer, and he, appearing, was immediately taken before the statue of the Goddess of Liberty, and there formally invested with a red cap, and sworn as a member of the community. The ceremony over, he was at once conducted to the fountain, which had been turned on again, and there, in the presence of the assembled people, was washed in its waters, as a purifying rite. The crowd then closed round him, and he was embraced by all, amid loud shouts of "Citizen Barnave!"
